July 21, 1991: Fiction
THE KITCHEN GOD'S WIFE, by Amy Tan. (Putnam, $22.95.) A Chinese-
American matriarch tells the harrowing story of her life.
THE FIRM, by John Grisham. (Doubleday, $19.95.) A young lawyer learns that his
firm is engaged in secret, possibly illegal activities.
HEIR TO THE EMPIRE, by Timothy Zahn. (Spectra/Bantam, $15.) The survival of
the "Star Wars" galaxy is menaced by new forces.
LOVES MUSIC, LOVES TO DANCE, by Mary Higgins Clark. (Simon & Schuster,
$21.95.) Two Manhattan women, doing research into personal ads, get caught in
the snare of a serial killer.
BEAST, by Peter Benchley. (Random House, $21.) The disappearance of a
couple sailing off Bermuda raises a question: is a fabled creature from the deep
responsible?
PARADISE, by Judith McNaught. (Pocket, $19.95.) The heirs of two family
dynasties find true love when one of their businesses is threatened.
AS THE CROW FLIES, by Jeffrey Archer. (HarperCollins, $22.95.) Inspired by his
grandfather, a London vendor, a man strives to create the biggest store in the
world.
OH, THE PLACES YOU'LL GO! by Dr. Seuss. (Random House, $12.95.) The
problems of finding your way through life; in verse and pictures.
THE PIRANHAS, by Harold Robbins. (Simon & Schuster, $21.95.) A young man
discovers the ways of Hollywood, Wall Street and organized crime.
THE RUSTLERS OF WEST FORK, by Louis L'Amour. (Bantam, $18.) A frontier
novel featuring Hopalong Cassidy, first published in 1951.
VORTEX, by Larry Bond. (Warner, $21.95.) A war in southern Africa, sometime in
the future, involves Cuba and the United States.
DARKNESS, by John Saul. (Bantam, $17.50.) A family moves back to a Florida
town, where something evil awaits.
"H" IS FOR HOMICIDE, by Sue Grafton. (Holt, $17.95.) The private eye Kinsey
Millhone on the trail of two perpetrators of an insurance scam.
A SOLDIER OF THE GREAT WAR, by Mark Helprin. (Harcourt Brace Jovanovich,
$24.95.) An elderly Italian professor recalls a life spent as soldier, hero, deserter,
lover and family man.
IMMORTALITY, by Milan Kundera. (Grove Weidenfeld, $21.95.) Through the lives
Non-Fiction
CHUTZPAH, by Alan M. Dershowitz. (Little, Brown, $22.95.) A prominent law
professor's reflections on the lot of Jews in America, past, present and future.
IRON JOHN, by Robert Bly. (Addison-Wesley, $19.95.) The passage of the male
from boyhood into manhood, as practiced in various cultures.
PARLIAMENT OF WHORES, by P. J. O'Rourke. (Entrekin/Atlantic Monthly,
$19.95.) A humorist's attempt to explain the Federal Government.
THE COMMANDERS, by Bob Woodward. (Simon & Schuster, $24.95.) How the
President and his high military commanders made their decisions during the first
two years of the Bush Administration.
BOSS OF BOSSES, by Joseph F. O'Brien and Andris Kurins. (Simon & Schuster,
$22.95.) Two former F.B.I. agents report on the downfall of Paul Castellano, head
of the Gambino crime family.
FIRE IN THE BELLY, by Sam Keen. (Bantam, $19.95.) The changing role of
today's male.
A QUESTION OF CHARACTER, by Thomas C. Reeves. (Free Press, $24.95.) A
biography of John F. Kennedy.
TOUJOURS PROVENCE, by Peter Mayle. (Knopf, $20.) The charms of rustic
Provence, as savored by a London advertising man who moved there.
PAUL HARVEY'S FOR WHAT IT'S WORTH, edited by Paul Harvey Jr. (Bantam,
$15.) Anecdotes told by the radio broadcaster.
COUNSEL TO THE PRESIDENT, by Clark Clifford with Richard Holbrooke.
(Random House, $25.) The memoirs of the lawyer who served as adviser to
several generations of Democrats.
DAVE BARRY TALKS BACK, by Dave Barry. (Crown, $18.) A collection of
columns by the syndicated humorist.
SILENT COUP, by Len Colodny and Robert Gettlin. (St. Martin's, $24.95.) The
events that led to the resignation of President Richard Nixon.
WOODY ALLEN, by Eric Lax. (Knopf, $24.) The life of the film director, writer and
actor.
UNDER THE INFLUENCE, by Peter Hernon and Terry Ganey. (Simon &
Schuster, $24.95.) An unauthorized account of Anheuser-Busch.
BULLY FOR BRONTOSAURUS, by Stephen Jay Gould. (Norton, $22.95.) Essays
on natural history.
